summary: adult patients with severe HAP required admission to intensive care unit. 107 patients (40.8%) underwent bronchoscopic BAL for etiologic diagnosis. most commonly identified viruses were respiratory syncytial virus and parainfluenza virus. viral pathogens are not uncommon in adult patients with severe HAP. hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) is the second most common nosocomial infection. severe HAP requiring treatment in the intensive care unit (ICU) is associated with high morbidity and mortality. the incidence of viral infection has been considerably underestimated in the absence of PCR [9], [10], [22]. no investigation has been focused on the role of viral infection as a cause of HAP. prospective cohort study conducted between march, 2010 and february, 2012. all consecutive adult patients with severe HAP were included in the study. disease severity was evaluated by the Acute Physiological and Chronic Health Evaluation (APACHE) II and the Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) score. microorganisms identified from specimens collected within 72 hours after pneumonia diagnosis were included as pathogens. PCR was used to detect atypical bacterial pathogens such as L. pneumophila, Mycoplasma pneumoniae and Legionella pneumophila.
